database_info.name: Ticinese Grammar Rules Database
database_info.region: Canton Ticino, Switzerland and Northern Lombardy, Italy
database_info.classification: Indo-European → Romance → Gallo-Italic → Lombard → Western Lombard → Alpine Lombard → Ticinese
database_info.sources: Perplexity Pro Research, Academic linguistic databases, Historical texts

grammar_rules.rule_name: Mandatory subject clitics for 2nd and 3rd person
grammar_rules.description: Ticinese employs a dual pronoun system with mandatory weak pronouns (clitics) for second and third person singular and third person plural. Pattern: (Strong Subject) + Weak Subject + Verb
grammar_rules.exceptions: First person singular and plural, and second person plural do not require weak pronouns: 'Mi magni' (I eat), 'Num magnòm' (we eat)
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian doesn't use doubled pronouns: 'Lui mangia' not *'Lui el mangia'
grammar_rules.source: Perplexity Research - Core Western Lombard grammatical feature

grammar_rules.description: Basic word order follows SVO pattern with mandatory subject clitics. Full pattern: (Strong Subject) + Weak Subject + Predicate + Direct Object + Other Complements
examples_ticinese: Lù el canta una canzun bela
La nonna la magna pan e formai
examples_english: The grandmother eats bread and cheese
grammar_rules.exceptions: In questions, inversion may occur in archaic forms
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Similar SVO order but without mandatory clitics

grammar_rules.rule_name: Strict ordering of multiple pronominal particles
grammar_rules.description: When multiple pronominal particles co-occur, strict ordering applies: Weak Subject + Indirect Object Particle + Direct Object Particle + Verb
examples_ticinese: Lù el ghe m'ha imprestad un liber
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian has similar but slightly different ordering rules

grammar_rules.rule_name: Four-conjugation verb system preserved from Latin
grammar_rules.description: Ticinese preserves the Latin four-conjugation system with regular verbs conjugated according to infinitive endings: -à (first), -é (second), -er (third), -ì (fourth)
examples_ticinese: parlà (1st): mi parli, ti parlet, lù parla, num parlom
vedé (2nd): mi védi, ti védet, lù véd, num védom
sentí (4th): mi sénti, ti séntet, lù sént, num séntom
examples_english: speak: I speak, you speak, he speaks, we speak
see: I see, you see, he sees, we see
hear: I hear, you hear, he hears, we hear
grammar_rules.exceptions: Several irregular verbs: fà, andà, dà, stà, savé, volé, podé

grammar_rules.rule_name: Definite articles with gender and regional variation
grammar_rules.description: Definite articles display gender and number agreement with regional variation. Masculine: el/ol/al (before consonants), l' (before vowels). Feminine: la (before consonants), l' (before vowels). Plural: i/le (regional variation)
grammar_rules.exceptions: Article form varies by subregion within Ticino
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian uses il/lo/la/i/gli/le with similar but distinct distribution

grammar_rules.description: Indefinite articles: on (masculine), ona (feminine) meaning 'a/an'. Partitive articles use di/de + definite article for 'some': del pàn (some bread)
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian uses un/una and del/della similarly

grammar_rules.rule_name: Past and future tense formation patterns
grammar_rules.description: Imperfect tense adds -avi/-évi/-ivi suffixes. Future tense employs -aroo/-aree/-arà/-arèmm/-arii/-arann patterns. Both show regular conjugation within verb classes.
examples_ticinese: Future: mi parlaroo, ti parlaree, lù parlarà
examples_english: Imperfect: I was speaking, you were speaking
Future: I will speak, you will speak, he will speak
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian has similar but distinct tense endings

grammar_rules.description: Negation particles vary regionally. Simple tenses: negation after verb. Compound tenses: negation between auxiliary and participle. Infinitive: negation before infinitive.
examples_ticinese: Lù el canta minga (He doesn't sing)
Lù l'ha minga cantad (He hasn't sung)
grammar_rules.exceptions: Conservative dialects use postposed nò: 'Lù el canta nò'

grammar_rules.description: Double negation is grammatically emphatic and absolute. Combines negative particles with negative indefinites.
examples_ticinese: Mi no vedi pu nagot (I don't see anything anymore)
No l'hoo mai vedud (I've never seen it - archaic 1850-1915)
grammar_rules.exceptions: None - double negation intensifies rather than cancels
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian also uses double negation: 'non vedo niente'

grammar_rules.description: Modern form maintains SVO order with rising intonation. Archaic 1850s form employed verb-pronoun inversion.
examples_ticinese: Modern: Lù l'è grand? (Is he great?)
Archaic: Lù e'l grand? (Is he great?)
grammar_rules.exceptions: Inversion more common in formal or archaic texts
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian uses similar intonation or 'è vero che...'

grammar_rules.rule_name: Content questions with fronted interrogative pronouns
grammar_rules.description: Interrogative pronouns (chi, cossa, quanta, indove, quandè, comè) introduce content questions with fronting to sentence-initial position.
examples_ticinese: Chi te amet? (Who do you love?)
Cossa te see dree a fa? (What are you doing?)
Quanta carn te hee mangiad? (How much meat did you eat?)
Quandè te faree quella roba chì? (When will you do that?)
Comè che t'hee fad? (How did you do it?)
examples_english: How much meat did you eat?
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian has similar wh-fronting: 'Chi ami?', 'Cosa fai?'

grammar_rules.description: Common prepositions contract regularly with definite articles. Patterns: de + el = del, a + el = al, in + el = nel
grammar_rules.exceptions: Some prepositions don't contract: cun, per
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian has similar contractions: del, al, nel, etc.

grammar_rules.rule_name: Direct and indirect object pronoun placement
grammar_rules.description: Direct object pronouns employ both proclitic (before verb) and enclitic (after verb) forms. Proclitic: me, te, el/l'/la, i. Enclitic: -m, -t, -l/-la, -i. Indirect object pronouns predominantly use 'ghe' across persons.
examples_ticinese: El ghe l'ha dad (He gave it to him/her)
grammar_rules.exceptions: Enclitic forms attach to imperatives and infinitives

grammar_rules.rule_name: Possessive pronouns with and without articles
grammar_rules.description: Archaic (1850-1915) rustic forms omit definite article before possessives: 'mé pader' (my father). Modern forms include article: 'el mé pader'. Forms: mé/mia (my), to/toa (your), so/soa (his/her), nòst/nòsta (our), vòst/vòsta (your pl), so/soa (their)
grammar_rules.exceptions: Article usage varies by register and period
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian always uses article: 'il mio padre'
grammar_rules.time_period: Archaic without article: 1200-1900, Modern with article: 1850-present

grammar_rules.description: Demonstrative pronouns distinguish proximity. Near speaker: chel/chell (this). Far from speaker: quel/quell (that). Both show gender and number agreement.

grammar_rules.rule_name: Universal weak pronoun 'a' for existential statements
grammar_rules.description: Universal weak pronoun 'a' functions for existential and impersonal statements. Common pattern: a gh'era (there was), a gh'è (there is)
examples_ticinese: A gh'era on temporal de foeura (There was a storm outside)
A gh'è del pàn (There is some bread)
grammar_rules.exceptions: None - 'a' is obligatory in these constructions

grammar_rules.description: Historical Ticinese (1850-1915) shows consistent past participle gender-number agreement with subject, especially in compound tenses with auxiliary verb.
examples_ticinese: La duna l'è vegnuda (The woman has come - feminine)
El oman l'è vegnud (The man has come - masculine)
I donn hin vegnude (The women have come - fem. pl.)
I omen hin vegnud (The men have come - masc. pl.)

grammar_rules.description: Historical Ticinese texts (1850-1915) display doubled consonants in stressed verbal forms, especially with auxiliary 'have'.
grammar_rules.exceptions: Modern orthography tends toward single consonants
grammar_rules.comparison_italian: Italian doesn't double in these contexts: 'ho'
